passages.text: Economics - Asia ex-Japan
Following the second extra budget, we expect domestic demand to rebound, which would support stronger Q3 GDP growth.

- IP growth slowed to \(0.3\%\) m-o-m, as in July from \(1.7\%\) in June (Consensus: \(0.2\%\); Nomura: \(1.9\%\) ), owing to weaker production in chips (-3.6%) and auto vehicles & parts (-7.3%), offsetting strong production in electronic parts (20.9%). However, year-on-year growth in IP picked up sharply \(5.0\%\) in July from \(1.6\%\) in June, suggesting underlying growth trends have held up relatively well. Reflecting weaker activity in the manufacturing and services sectors, all industry production growth also slowed.- Domestic demand picked up, with retail sales and business facility investment growth increasing and offsetting weaker construction activity. Key activity directly related to service consumption also picked up, though headline growth in service production slowed due to weaker activity in the finance sector.- Nomura-KRnow is tracking Q3 GDP growth at \(1.1\%\) q-o-q, sa (our base case forecast: \(1.1\%\) ), up from \(0.6\%\) in Q2, indicating a strong recovery ahead. We maintain our 2025 GDP growth forecast of \(1.0\%\) (BOK: \(0.9\%\) ).- We expect the BOK to focus more on forward-looking downside risk due to higher tariffs despite the near-term strong pick up in headline growth. So, we maintain our forecast for two more 25bp cuts in October and February (terminal rate: \(2.00\%\) ). However, because of the BOK's cautious economic outlook, we believe the risk is skewed towards faster cuts rather than slower cuts. We now assign a \(15\%\) probability to consecutive cuts in Q4, reflecting the BOK's preference for pre-emptive action against downside risks.

IP growth slowed to \(0.3\%\) m- o- m, as in July from \(1.7\%\) in June (Consensus: \(0.2\%\) ; Nomura: \(1.9\%\) ; Figure 1) owing to weaker production in chips (- 3.6%) and auto vehicles & parts (- 7.3%), offsetting strong production in electronic parts (20.9%), though year- on- year growth in IP continued to rise, to \(5.0\%\) y- o- y in July from \(1.6\%\) in June (Consensus: \(3.9\%\) ; Nomura: \(5.7\%\) ; Service production growth slowed, led by the finance sector, though activity closely related to domestic consumption (wholesale & retail, hotels & restaurants) strengthened. All industry production growth (which includes the manufacturing and service sectors) slowed to \(0.3\%\) m- o- m, as in July from \(1.5\%\) in June.

Retail sales growth (goods consumption) picked up sharply to \(2.5\%\) m- o- m, as in July from \(0.7\%\) in June, led by strong auto vehicle sales. Investment growth generally improved in July, with business facility investment rising sharply, offsetting the decline in construction activity.
The trend- adjusted coincident index fell to 99pt in July from 99.1pt in June, while the trend- adjusted leading index rose to 101.5pt in July from 101pt in June.

Nomura's view: Improving domestic demand supports a strong pickup in Q3 GDP Amid solid export growth, consumption vouchers are driving a recovery in consumption, as evidenced by the strong pickup in service consumption. At the same time, improving sentiment also likely encouraged consumers to buy more durable goods. Nomura- KRnow is tracking Q3 GDP growth at \(1.1\%\) q- o- q, sa (Figure 2; our base case: \(1.1\%\) ), up from \(0.6\%\) in Q2, indicating a strong recovery ahead. We maintain our 2025 GDP growth forecast of \(1.0\%\) (BOK: \(0.9\%\) ).
Despite these encouraging signs of a domestic revival, the BOK appears increasingly

focused on forward-looking risks, and likely downplays a near-term bounce in growth. Its recent downward revision of its export growth forecast in 2026 to - 0.1% signals deep-seated concerns about the external sector, particularly in light of the higher tariffs.

Because of the BOK's forward-looking caution, we maintain our forecast for two more 25bp cuts in October and February, which would lower the policy rate to 2.00% by end-2026 from 2.50% currently. However, the risks are increasingly skewed toward faster easing - and we now assign a 15% probability to consecutive cuts in Q4, reflecting the BOK's preference for pre-emptive action against downside risks.
Fig. 1: Korea: Economic activity heat map
